text.p: These are leading stories in this morning's Paris newspapers.

-- Prime Minister Alain Juppe decides not to extend a government incentive package granted to buyers of new cars, beyond Monday expiry date. Last month of scheme boosted auto sales, with a record 200,000 orders in September.(Les Echos, La Tribune, Le Figaro, Liberation).
-- Court puts airline Air Liberte under legal administration for six-month period. (Les Echos, La Tribune, Le Figaro, Liberation)
-- British Telecom to invest 8.85 billion francs in Generale des Eaux telecoms branch Cegetel, along with Germen Mannesman and U.S. SBC. (Les Echos, La Tribune, Le Figaro, Liberation)
-- Paribas posts a four-billion-franc profit for the first half.
-- Alcatel Alsthom and SNECMA expect to break even by end of year.
-- Textile group DMC to shed 1,500 jobs in Germany and France.
-- CGIP says plans to buy a 28 percent stake in auto parts maker Valeo from holding Cerus, plans to sell stake in U.S. packaging group Crown Cork and Seal for around 3 billion francs.
-- Cost of explosion of Ariane-5 rocket in June 1996 estimated around 2 billion francs.
-- Luxury goods group LVMH profits climb five percent to 1.54 billion francs, but gray market weighs on earnings.
